did.unittitle: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia Malacology Department records

bioghist.p: The collection of recent mollusks at The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia is the oldest in the country, and the second largest catalogued one in the world. It currently has more than 430,000 catalogued lots containing about 12 million specimens, including 30,000-35,000 lots preserved in ethanol. Type specimens of more than 400 authors are represented in more than 12,000 type lots. The Academy has specimens from all over the world. Greatest strengths are in shallow-water marine mollusks from the tropical Indo-Pacific and the Western Atlantic and worldwide freshwater and land mollusks. The staff of the department maintain this collection and conduct research.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to the Malacology Department of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. Materials include Robert Robertson's correspondence 1953-1983, arranged by correspondent; correspondence, reprints, and bulletins kept by various other members of the Department of Malacology, including George Davis, Horace Richards, Earl A. Shapiro, Robert Robertson, and Gary Rosenberg; miscellaneous correspondence and records related to specimens (1939-1976). The collection also includes catalogs and records of the specimen collections, including materials related to the collections of Olaf Oswald, John H. Redfield, H.A. Pilsbry, E.D. Cope, and R.E. Griffith; a volume listing donations to the Academy's conchological section (1867-1874); Department of Geology and Paleontology reports (1957-1972), a list of the publications of Earl Spamer; and glass plate negatives for the Manual of Conchology, Volumes 1, 2, and 7, published between 1879 and 1885. The collection also includes 18 rolled wall charts of mollusks, circa 1930s.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia Geology and Paleontology Department records, George Davis papers, Robert Robertson papers, Horace G.
